Evacuation of Personnel: In the event of an emergency determined to be motive fluid system-related and evacuation is deemed necessary, the control room operator or other designated personnel will sound the plant evacuation alarm if not automatically initiated by gas or flame detectors.

First Aid: All personnel have been trained in adult CPR and basic first aid procedures.

Control Room Operator: Upon notification from the site that an emergency has occurred, the Control
Room Operator shall verify an emergency shutdown of the plant was initiated, and emergency response teams have been called. The Control Room Operator assumes initial communications with the site over emergencies until relieved by either the Plant Manager or Operations Manager.

Emergency Response Personnel: Fire, police, and/or ambulance crews will be called as necessary.
The senior employee on-site during the incident will report to the person in charge of the emergency teams. This report will include currently known causes and effects, reports of injured personnel and their locations, etc. All other employees are instructed to stay clear unless specifically requested to assist in some manner.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety: The plant has been operating safely for many years. Ormat will continue to ensure extensive training for the operators as they are essential to plant safety. In addition to implementing recommendations generated by the PHA, Ormat will continue to evaluate any new mitigation or control technology that may improve safety at the Brady Geothermal Power Plant.

The PHA will be updated and revalidated at least every five years to ensure the study is consistent for the life of the OEC processes.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of normal butane or iso-pentane.  

Emergency Response Program:  The Emergency Action Plan is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. The EAP procedures apply to all personnel working at the Brady Geothermal facility.  The EAP is submitted to the local fire department for review and approval when changes are made to the plan. The following information was selectively excerpted from the Brady Geothermal Emergency Action Plan (EAP).

Motive Fluid Leak or Fire Emergencies: An emergency is identified as any fire, explosion, or motive fluid spill (ruptured vessel, process pipe, etc.) within the plant. Under no circumstances is any person to put himself/herself in danger. A General Response and Action Chart has been prepared to guide the initial response and follow-up actions in case of a motive fluid vapor, smoke, or fire detection alarm.

Implementation, Control, and Compliance: The Operations and Maintenance Manager is responsible for developing and implementing the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan shall be reviewed annually to verify regulatory compliance and accuracy with both OSHA Regulations on
Emergency Plans 29, CFR 1910.38 and NDEP-CAPP's Emergency Response Programs, NAC
459.9544. The Emergency Response Program must also be periodically reviewed and updated, and employees must be notified of any changes in conformance with 40 CFR 68.95. Relief system design: Relief valves are located on the storage tank, OEC vaporizers, and condensers. Each pressure relief valve relieves directly to the atmosphere, and some installations have extension pipes installed to direct the relief valve discharge away from critical machinery. Additionally, each pressure relief valve is installed immediately above a rupture disk designed to fail at the relief pressure of its corresponding relief valve. Individual relief valve locations are equipped with telltale gauges between the relief valve and its rupture disk to easily identify leaking or blown rupture disks.

Ventilation System Design: All components of the motive fluid transfer and storage system and the
OEC units are located outdoors and well-ventilated.

Safety Systems: Beyond the relief system, the Brady OEC units have extensive fire protection, detection, and alarming systems and an administrative control system for fire prevention.
The fire detection systems include gas monitors, continuously monitoring the area surrounding the OECs, and multi-spectrum infrared flame detectors throughout the plant. The facility has a fire water loop around the plant within reach of the OECs and storage tanks. The fire water loops consist of fire pumps, water tanks, monitors, hydrants, and a deluge system for the iso-pentane storage tank.  The butane storage tank is coated with fireproofing insulation that prevents the tank shell from overheating for up to two hours without fire water application to help prevent a tank boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion.  Operators are trained in properly using the installed fire protection equipment, and the facility operator appropriately documents the training information.

Initial and refresher training is documented and maintained per the requirements of the Training Program.
Contracted employees shall be trained in the Emergency Action Plan procedure requirements before working at the Brady site. Training includes the following items but is not limited to (a) Location and sounds of the gas, fire, and evacuation alarms and detectors; (b) Expectations of response to injuries and emergencies by personnel on site; and (c) Evacuation routes and locations.
Refresher training for all personnel shall be conducted annually at a minimum.
Safety Training: Some equipment at the Brady Power Plant poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the site hazards. These subjects include Emergency Action Plan (EAP), motive fluid hazards, fire prevention and hot work, lock-out and tag-out procedures, hazard communication, confined space, hearing conservation, personal protective equipment, accident, injury, and incident reporting. Safety training is supplemented by the use of Standard Safety Procedures.

OEC Units: The OEC units are controlled and monitored by their own dedicated Programmable
Logic Controller (PLC). The PLC receives all discrete (logic) and analog signals from the input devices (e.g., switches and measuring sensors), processes the signals according to pre-loaded Ormat software, and then outputs logic and analog command signals to local and field devices. The proper measuring instruments measure all parameters needed for the proper operation of the OEC units, such as pressure, temperature, voltage, current, power, speed, etc. The PLC will immediately detect deviation from the operating parameters, and the PLC will initiate correction, Alarms, or automatic s

ning process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.

Maintenance Procedures: A Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP) has been developed for the Brady facility. The MIP adopts a maintenance concept for periodic preventative and corrective maintenance of the OEC system. The preventative maintenance tasks include visual inspection, lubricating rotating parts, system cleaning, replacing liquids and filters, and periodic tests to verify the system is operating correctly. Preventative maintenance tasks and procedures are scheduled over a series of maintenance intervals. The Mechanical Integrity Program identifies system maintenance procedures, frequencies and spare parts, manufacturer recommendations, operational experience, and best practices.

Alarm system maintenance is determined using a combination of regulatory requirements, manufacturer's recommendations, plant operating experience, and best practices.

Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs give detailed, safe operating instructions on Normal Operations, Plant Startup and Shutdown, and Emergency Operations. Additionally covered are operations of Fire Protection and Gas Detection Systems, Electrical Distribution Systems, Butane, and Pentane Systems, Brine Systems, Evacuation, Transfer, and Storage Systems, Non-Condensable Gas Removal Systems, Turbine Controls, and Support Systems, Compressed Air Systems, and Cooling Water Systems.

Training: Initial training for personnel is given before an employee is allowed to operate or work on the facility's process area or process equipment. Training Qualifications for operation and maintenance personnel are required and renewed periodically to validate knowledge and understanding of expected work performance. Ormat's Western Nevada Operations Group operates the Brady Power Plant. The WNV Operations
Group (WNVOPS) comprises management, administration, maintenance, engineering, and operations personnel.  WNVOPS operates the Western Nevada power generation facilities owned or operated by Ormat.

Brady is a remotely operated facility.  Remote operations are conducted from the Galena 3 control room in Reno, NV.  On-site staff will typically consist of one plant operator, two maintenance personnel, and two electrical personnel, which are shared between another local facility and the
Brady facility.  Management support is staffed at the Brady facility, including an Operations and Maintenance Manager and a Maintenance Supervisor.  Additional operational, maintenance, and administrative support is provided to the Brady facility from the Steamboat Complex in Reno, NV.  The Brady facility operates continuously 24 hours a day and 365 days a year (excluding scheduled maintenance downtime or plant upsets).

Regulated Substance Handled:  The Brady Geothermal Power Plant utilizes normal butane in OEC-1 and iso-pentane in OEC-2 as its motive fluids.  Each OEC contains more than the 10,000-pound threshold quantity.

Brady Geothermal Power Plant Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary (revision 2, May 10, 2023)

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Brady Power Partner's policy is to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The Brady
Geothermal facility actively manages all operational permits and safety programs, such as Nevada
Department of Environmental Protection Air Quality, Chemical Accident Prevention Program,
Underground Injection Control as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management. Ormat is committed to handling flammable motive fluid systems in a safe manner to protect the environment. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses, and all other process safety management are maintained onsite for reference or are available electronically.

Facility Description
Brady Power Partners wholly own the Brady Geothermal Power Plant. The Brady
Geothermal facility is located in Churchill County. The physical plant is located at 7042 Old Highway
40, east of Fernley, Nevada. The leased acreage covers the defined geothermal resource area and reinjection zones.

Prior to March 2018, the Brady facility consisted of three steam-powered turbines and one OEC (Ormat Energy Converter), aka existing OEC.  Since then, Ormat has added one new OEC and just recently completed the revamp of the existing OEC.  The new OEC process is named OEC-1, and the existing OEC process is named OEC-2.  The three steam-powered turbines have been decommissioned.

This RMP submission reflects the new OEC-1 and the revamped process, OEC-2. 

Under the current configuration, Brady is supplied hot geothermal brine from six pumped production wells.  OEC-1 and OEC-2 process the brine through a closed loop, binary Rankine Cycle.  The hot brine circulates through the tube side of the shell and tube heat exchangers to preheat and vaporize the motive fluid on the shell side.
